revision.text:
The '''92nd Training Centre''' was a formation of the [[Ukrainian Ground Forces]], that drew most of its history from the '''92nd Guards Rifle Division''', that became the '''92nd Guards Motor Rifle Division''' in 1965.
The 92nd Guards Rifle Division was formed in March 1943 in Kupyansk from the soldiers of the 149th and 12th Guards Rifle Brigades involved in the [[Battle of Stalingrad]]. 93rd Rifle Brigade was established in September 1942 in the Urals. Became 12th Guards Rifle Brigade, then in April 1943, 92nd Guards RD.<ref>“Red Banner from Ural", Military Publishing, 1983, p. 137, via Lenskii 2001.</ref>
In the summer of 1943 fighters division participated in the battles in [[Prokhorovka, Belgorod Oblast|Prokhorovka]], then at [[Kharkiv]], [[Poltava]], [[Voznesensk]], [[Pervomaisk, Mykolaiv Oblast|Pervomaysk]].
On 1 September 1943 the division was part of the [[57th Rifle Corps]]. The corps comprised the [[62nd Guards Rifle Division|62nd Guards]], 92nd Guards, [[110th Guards Rifle Division|110th Guards]], and [[53rd Rifle Division (Soviet Union)|53rd Rifle Division]]s. It was part of the 37th Army, STAVKA Reserve.
In 1943 the division liberated [[Kryvyi Rih]], for which the division was named Krivorozhskaya. Crossed the [[River Dnieper]] near the village of Mishurin Horn. Soon the division was awarded the Order of the Red Banner.
Fought in Moldavia, and Iasi in Romania. With [[37th Army (Soviet Union)|37th Army]] in Bulgaria May 1945. 48 fighters of the division were awarded the title of Hero of the Soviet Union.
In 1946, the division was relocated to the city of [[Mykolaiv]], [[Odessa Military District]]. Became 34th Guards Mechanised Division postwar, 34th Guards Motor Rifle Division 1957, and 92nd Guards Motor Rifle Division on 11 January 1965.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ww2.dk/new/army/msd/92gvmsd.htm|title=92nd Guards Training Motorised Rifle Division|last=Holm|first=Michael|website=www.ww2.dk|access-date=2016-05-18}}</ref> On 14 September 1987, it became the 150th Guards District Training Centre.
After the Soviet collapse, the division became part of the Ukrainian Armed Forces. Colonel Valery Alexandrovich Ageyev, Commanding the 150th Training Centre for Young Specialists, of the Odessa Military District was promoted to Major-General in Decree 350/93 of 21 August 1993.<ref>[http://zakon4.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/350/93 Edict of the President of Ukraine on conferring military ranks], 21 August 1993.</ref> Duncan noted in April 1997 that '..the motor rifle training centre remain[s] under the command of the new MD.'<ref>Andrew Duncan, 'Ukraine's forces find that change is good,' [[Jane's Intelligence Review]], April 1997, p.163</ref>
Later it was redesignated the 92nd Training Centre of the [[Southern Operational Command]] (92 УЦ ЮОК).
==Composition==
*276th Guards Rifle Regiment *280th Guards Rifle Regiment *282nd Guards Rifle Regiment *197th Guards Artillery Regiment
==References== <references/>
==External links== *http://www.ww2.dk/new/army/msd/92gvmsd.htm
